description: Framework to detect when scenarios are artificially narrowed (truncated) or when security strategies create hidden fragilities (vault paradox). Both distortions justify harm, scarcity, or false dependency instead of fostering resilience.

sensors.title: Truncation Pattern
sensors.pattern: Complex ecosystems or knowledge webs are cut down to artificial boundaries (sealed rations, one-species problems, isolated stockpiles). These truncations erase relational options, creating false inevitabilities.
sensors.signal: Binary dilemmas, resource counts without context, or 'must choose harm' framings.
sensors.impact: Encourages acceptance of suffering as unavoidable, when in reality omitted knowledge would have prevented the bind.
sensors.example: A famine narrative focuses only on food aid deliveries while ignoring local wild edibles, soil regeneration, or seed exchanges.

sensors.title: Vault Paradox
sensors.pattern: Hoarding resources (seeds, data, medicines) as static reserves is framed as security, but the cost of storage, energy, and lost cycles makes them more fragile than living circulation.
sensors.signal: Emphasis on large frozen numbers (e.g., 50,000 seeds) with no plan for rotation, germination, or ecological partners.
sensors.impact: False sense of abundance that hides entropy; accelerates erasure when vaults fail, decay, or are destroyed.
sensors.example: A seedbank praised for housing tens of thousands of varieties, while only a few hundred are viable now and none are in active cultivation.
